text: Introduction to Clinical Pharmacology Chapter 31 Lower Respiratory System Drugs Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer · All Rights Reserved Learning Objectives 1. Explain the uses, general drug actions, general adverse reactions, contraindications, precautions, and interactions of the bronchodilators and antiasthma drugs. 2. Distinguish important preadministration and ongoing assessment activities the nurse should perform on the client taking a bronchodilator or an antiasthma drug. 3. List nursing diagnoses particular to a client taking a bronchodilator or an antiasthma drug. 4. Examine ways to promote an optimal response to therapy, how to manage common adverse reactions, and important points to keep in mind when educating a client about the use of bronchodilators or antiasthma drugs. flow meter reading o Auscultate breath sounds o Description of sputum o Signs of hypoxia o Cyanosis of skin or mucous membranes o Laboratory tests: ABG, PFT Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer · All Rights Reserved Nursing Process—Client Receiving a Lower Respiratory System Drug #2 ❖ Preadministration Assessment (continued) ❖ Subjective Data o Type and duration of symptoms o Description of any environmental triggers o Description of activity disruption by symptoms o Health history (especially regarding seasonal allergies or allergens in household) o Remedies attempted before seeking care Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer · All Rights Reserved Nursing Process—Client Receiving a Lower Respiratory System Drug #3 ❖ Ongoing Assessment—Acute Asthma Attack o Assess the respiratory status about 30 minutes after drug is administered and every 4 hours (or more often if needed) and whenever drug is administered o Focused respiratory assessment o Keep record of intake and output o Report any imbalance o After administration observe the client for the effectiveness of the drug Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer · All Rights Reserved Nursing Process—Client Receiving a Lower Respiratory System Drug #4 ❖ Ongoing Assessment—Stable Chronic o Client self-monitors o Utilize asthma action plan to assess and treat appropriately o Nurse asks client about changes seen on the asthma action plan (i.e., have client’s status been in the green, yellow, or red zone) o Monitor for chest pain and changes in ECG in clients with a history of cardiovascular problems o Pulmonary function tests and comparison to baseline Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer · All Rights Reserved Nursing Process—Client Receiving a Lower Respiratory System Drug #5 ❖ Nursing Diagnosis o Anxiety related to feelings of breathlessness o Ineffective Airway Clearance related to bronchospasm o Impaired Oral Mucous Membranes related to dryness or irritation o Malnutrition Risk: Less Than Body Requirements related to o Expected client outcomes depend on the reason for administration of the drug but include: ▪ Optimal response to therapy ▪ Management of adverse drug reactions ▪ Confidence in an understanding of the prescribed medication regimen Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer · All Rights Reserved Nursing Process—Client Receiving a Lower Respiratory System Drug #7 ❖ Implementation o Promoting Optimal Response to Therapy ▪ Careful monitoring of the client ▪ Instruction on proper administration of various drugs Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer · All Rights Reserved Nursing Process—Client Receiving a Lower Respiratory System Drug #8 ❖ Implementation o Promoting Optimal Response to Therapy o Quick Relief for Acute Symptom Intervention ▪ Instruct client to administer 2 to 4 puffs of the inhaled SABA when acute distress occurs; up to 3 treatments in 20-minute intervals may be administered ▪ Consider the use of nebulized drugs if metered dose inhaler is difficult to use or ineffective for the client ➢ ICS and SABA—reduces inflammation and dilates bronchioles ➢ Racemic epinephrine—to relieve croup symptoms in children ➢ Antibiotics and mucolytics treat lung infections or loosen secretions of cystic fibrosis clients Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer · All Rights Reserved Nursing Process—Client Receiving a Lower Respiratory System Drug #9 ❖ Implementation o Promoting Optimal Response to Therapy o Quick Relief for Acute Symptom Intervention (continued) ▪ For a client in an urgent care or emergency care, epinephrine is administered subcutaneously for bronchospasm; minimize distractions while preparing; therapeutic effects last from 5 minutes to 4 hours ▪ Rapid theophyllinization is sometimes indicated through loading doses given orally or IV over 12 to 24 hours ▪ Monitor client closely for theophylline toxicity ▪ Monitor IV site to monitor for extravasation Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer · All Rights Reserved Nursing Process—Client Receiving a Lower Respiratory System Drug #10 ❖ Implementation o Promoting Optimal Response to Therapy o Long-Term Control of Symptoms ▪ Teach the client to use the stepwise method of self-care created by the primary health care provider to control respiratory mucosal inflammation ▪ Teach the client to refrain from swallowing the ICS’s and to rinse the mouth thoroughly after using the inhaler ▪ When taking oral corticosteroids, children are at risk for growth reduction so monitor height and weight; older adults are at risk of osteoporosis so calcium and vitamin D supplements may be prescribed Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer · All Rights Reserved Nursing Process—Client Receiving a Lower Respiratory System Drug #11 ❖ Implementation o Promoting Optimal Response to Therapy o Long-Term Control of Symptoms (continued) ▪ Teach clients that formoterol comes in a capsule but is administered through an Aerolizer inhaler; do not take orally ▪ Mast cell stabilizer cromolyn must be tapered if it is going to be discontinued; when administered orally, must be given 1.5 hours before meals and at bedtime. ▪ Oral cromolyn comes in an ampule and is poured into water to administer (do not administer with other liquids) Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer · All Rights Reserved Nursing Process—Client Receiving a Lower Respiratory System Drug #12 ❖ Implementation o Promoting Optimal Response to Therapy o Long-Term Control of Symptoms (continued) ▪ Never administer leukotriene receptor antagonists, inhibitors, and immunomodulators during an acute asthma attack (given orally and can worsen the attack) ▪ Before giving Zileuton and during therapy review hepatic aminotransferase levels for signs of liver dysfunction ▪ Clients are monitored after the injection of mepolizumab (given once a month) in a clinic setting for the development of anaphylaxis; teach client the reaction can occur up to 4 days following the injection Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer · All Rights Reserved Nursing Process—Client Receiving a Lower Respiratory System Drug #13 ❖ Implementation o Monitoring and Managing Client Needs ▪ Anxiety ➢Reassure the client that the medications will help relieve difficulty with breathing ➢Speak and act in a calm manner ➢Closely monitor the client’s respiratory rate and blood pressure and report and significant changes Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer · All Rights Reserved Nursing Process—Client Receiving a Lower Respiratory System Drug #14 ❖ Implementation o Monitoring and Managing Client Needs ▪ Ineffective Airway Clearance ➢Check the blood, pressure, pulse, respiratory rate, pulse oximetry, and response to the drug every 5 to 15 minutes until the client’s condition stabilizes and respiratory distress is relieved Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer · All Rights Reserved Nursing Process—Client Receiving a Lower Respiratory System Drug #15 ❖ Implementation o Monitoring and Managing Client Needs ▪ Impaired Oral Mucous Membranes ➢ Inhalers can cause infection with Candida albicans ➢ Instruct client to use strict oral hygiene, cleans the inhaler, and use proper technique when taking the inhaled drug ➢ Ensure the client brushes teeth daily after treatment Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer · All Rights Reserved Nursing Process—Client Receiving a Lower Respiratory System Drug #16 ❖ Implementation o Monitoring and Managing Client Needs ▪ Malnutrition: Less Than Body Requirements ➢ Clients experiencing nausea as an adverse effect should be offered frequent small meals rather than three large meals ➢ Meals should be followed by oral care ➢ Limit fluids ➢ Teach the client and family to have a clean relaxed atmosphere during meals Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer · All Rights Reserved Nursing Process—Client Receiving a Lower Respiratory System Drug #17 ❖ Implementation o Monitoring and Managing Client Needs ▪ Malnutrition: Less Than Body Requirements (continued) ➢Clients taking theophylline can experience heartburn ➢Instruct client to remain in an upright position and sleep with head of bed elevated ➢If the antiasthma drug creates a bad taste in the mouth, instruct the client to take frequent sips of water, suck on sugarless candy, or chew gum Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer · All Rights Reserved Pharmacology in Practice Exercise #3 ❖ A client complains of nausea after receiving an antiasthma medication. Which of the following instructions should the nurse provide to alleviate the client’s symptoms? Select all that apply. a) Keep the head of the bed elevated b) Eat frequent small meals c) Monitor blood pressure closely d) Limit fluids with meals e) Rinse mouth properly after eating Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer · All Rights Reserved Nursing Process—Client Receiving a Lower Respiratory System Drug #18 ❖ Implementation—Educating the Client and Family o Nurse’s role is to instruct the client and family in: ▪ methods to monitor the condition ▪ control triggers in the environment ▪ manage medications properly for optimal breathing Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer · All Rights Reserved Nursing Process—Client Receiving a Lower Respiratory System Drug #19 ❖ Implementation—Educating the Client and Family ❖ Teach the Client and Family: o To monitor breathing status and regulate medications based on the asthma action plan o How to use a peak flow meter and when to notify the primary health care provider o How to use an inhaler or nebulizer correctly and how to care for equipment Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer · All Rights Reserved Nursing Process—Client Receiving a Lower Respiratory System Drug #20 ❖ Evaluation o Was the therapeutic effect achieved and cough relieved? o Were adverse reactions: identified, reported, and managed? ▪ Anxiety is managed successfully ▪ Client has a clear patent airway ▪ Mucous membranes are moist and intact ▪ Nutrition is adequately maintained o Did client and family express confidence and demonstrate understanding of drug regimen?
